claim: If today is not Monday, then today is not Monday

supporting.text: The claim is a tautology, meaning it is logically true by definition.

attacks.text: The claim is a tautology, meaning it is logically true by definition.
Tautologies, while logically true, are vacuous and provide no meaningful information about the world.
Even if tautologies are vacuous, their logical validity remains useful in formal systems and proofs.

supporting.text: The statement 'if not Monday, then not Monday' is a repetition of the same condition, making it inherently true.

attacks.text: The statement 'if not Monday, then not Monday' is a repetition of the same condition, making it inherently true.

In logic, tautologies like this are considered valid and useful for establishing foundational truths, regardless of their apparent lack of novelty.

supporting.text: In propositional logic, the claim is of the form 'if P, then P,' which is always valid.

attacks.text: In propositional logic, the claim is of the form 'if P, then P,' which is always valid.
Propositional logic assumes a binary truth system, but real-world reasoning may involve fuzzy or multi-valued logic where 'if P, then P' is not universally valid.
Even in fuzzy or multi-valued logic, the identity implication 'if P, then P' holds as a tautology because it does not depend on the truth value of P.
